Type.Name: TreeModelSort

MemberSignature.Value: public void ClearCache ();
.method public hidebysig instance void ClearCache() cil managed

Docs.summary: * This function should almost never be called. It clears the TreeModelSort object of any cached iterators that haven't been reffed with . This might be useful if the child model being sorted is static (and doesn't change often) and there has been a lot of unreffed access to nodes. As a side effect of this function, all unreffed iters will be invalid.

Docs.summary: Returns the rows of this tree.
Docs.returns: A , true if this tree has children, false otherwise.
Docs.remarks: The underlying C call supports the specification of arbitrary parent rows to return children of, but the C# bindings assume that the root node is always the parent.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RefNode (Gtk.TreeIter iter);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void RefNode(valuetype Gtk.TreeIter iter) cil managed

Docs.summary: Lets the tree ref the node.

remarks.para: This is an optional method for models to implement. To be more specific, models may ignore this call as it exists primarily for performance reasons.

This function is primarily meant as a way for views to let caching models know when nodes are being displayed (and hence, whether or not to cache that node.) For example, a file-system based model would not want to keep the entire file-hierarchy in memory, just the sections that are currently being displayed by every current view.
A model should be expected to be able to get an iter independent of its referenced state.

MemberSignature.Value: public void UnrefNode (Gtk.TreeIter iter);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void UnrefNode(valuetype Gtk.TreeIter iter) cil managed

Docs.summary: Lets the tree unref the node.
Docs.remarks: This is an optional method for models to implement. To be more specific, models may ignore this call as it exists primarily for performance reasons. For more information on what this means, see . Please note that nodes that are deleted are not unreferenced.
